docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Bomber Kills 3 in Israel In a Blow to Peace Effort In the fifth attack against Israelis in less than 48 hours, a Palestinian suicide bomber detonated a shrapnel-packed bomb outside a mall in Afula, killing a security guard and two bystanders and delivering a new blow to a peace process that was already reeling. A1 Israel's forensic laboratory confirmed that a body found off a Tel Aviv beach was that of a Briton thought to have been involved in the April 30 nightclub attack that killed three people, the first suicide bombing to have been carried out by a non-Palestinian. A13

docs.lead_paragraph: About 20 percent of adolescents have had sexual intercourse before their 15th birthday -- and one in seven of the sexually experienced 14-year-old girls has been pregnant, according to a report released yesterday by the National Campaign to Prevent Teen Pregnancy. The report, an analysis of seven studies conducted in the late 1990's, offers a comprehensive look at the sexual activities of 12- to 14-year-olds, a group often overlooked in discussions of adolescent sexuality.

headline.main: 1 in 5 Teenagers Has Sex Before 15, Study Finds

docs.abstract: National Campaign to Prevent Teen Pregnancy reports analysis suggesting that about twenty percent of adolescents have sexual intercourse before their 15th birthdays, and one in seven of sexually experienced 14-year-old girls has been pregnant; report based on seven studies in late 1990's focuses on 12- to 14-year-olds; sexual activity is also correlated with risky behavior such as smoking, drinking and drug-taking (S)
docs.snippet: About 20 percent of adolescents have had sexual intercourse before their 15th birthday -- and one in seven of the sexually experienced 14-year-old girls has been pregnant, according to a report released yesterday by the National Campaign to Prevent...

docs.lead_paragraph: The mercury in ordinary saltwater fish eaten by pregnant women does not appear to affect their children, according to a study published on Friday in The Lancet. An earlier study of among Inuits in the Faeroe Islands found that children of women with higher mercury levels were more likely to have impaired language or attention skills at age 7.

headline.main: New Look at Fish and Pregnancy

docs.abstract: University of Rochester researcher Dr Gary J Myers leads study published in Lancet that discredits earlier data and shows that mothers who eat fish with standard levels of mercury cause no harm to their unborn children; study tested children in Seychelles, where women eat fish average of 12 times per week, and found children's scores were average on battery of developmental tests (S)
docs.snippet: The mercury in ordinary saltwater fish eaten by pregnant women does not appear to affect their children, according to a study published on Friday in The Lancet.    An earlier study of among Inuits in the Faeroe Islands found that children of women...

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, public health advocates were frustrated that most women did not know about a drug that could prevent pregnancy even if taken several days after sex. Its potential to reduce the abortion rate was enormous, and opponents of abortion generally did not oppose it. But that potential was unrealized, largely because the two companies distributing the drug in this country were so tiny that they could barely afford advertising. People who did know about it often confused it with RU-486, the abortion pill.

headline.main: Use of Morning-After Pill Rising And It May Go Over the Counter

docs.abstract: So-called morning after pill that could prevent pregnancy comes out of shadows; two companies distributing drug in United States are so tiny they could barely afford advertising, and people who do know about it often confuse it with RU-486, the abortion pill; now New Mexico has become fourth state to allow pharmacists to dispense drug directly to women, without doctor's prescription, and legislators or pharmacists in at least 14 states are agitating to do same; one company that sells pills, Women's Capital Corp, has applied to Food and Drug Adm for permission to sell its pill, called Plan B, over the counter; other, Gynetics, says it, too, expects its product, called Preven, to be sold over counter by end of next year; new research shows emergency contraceptive pill can prevent pregnancy even if taken five days after sex; pills are essentially birth control pills in higher doses; they are available over counter in more than dozen countries; photo (M)
docs.snippet: For years, public health advocates were frustrated that most women did not know about a drug that could prevent pregnancy even if taken several days after sex.    Its potential to reduce the abortion rate was enormous, and opponents of abortion...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Vincent J. Freda, a winner of a Lasker Award for medical research who helped develop a vaccine to prevent a disease that killed thousands of babies each year, died on May 7 at Columbia-Presbyterian Center in Manhattan. He was 75. The cause was respiratory failure, his family said.

headline.main: Vincent Freda, 75, Dies; Pioneered Vaccine to Save Babies

docs.abstract: Dr Vincent J Freda, winner of Lasker Award for medical research for his role in developing vaccine that helps women who have Rh-negative blood deliver healthy babies, dies at age 75; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Dr. Vincent J. Freda, a winner of a Lasker Award for medical research who helped develop a vaccine to prevent a disease that killed thousands of babies each year, died on May 7 at Columbia-Presbyterian Center in Manhattan. He was 75.    The cause was...

docs.lead_paragraph: MOST homeowners are aware that under current tax law, as much as $500,000 in gain realized from the sale of a principal residence owned and used for at least two years may be exempt from taxation. (The $500,000 exemption is the maximum exclusion for a married couple filing jointly; taxpayers filing individually get an exemption of up to $250,000.) There are times, however, when the gain on the sale of a home or an apartment is subject to tax. One such situation occurs when the taxpayer has not owned the property or lived in it for the require amount of time. Another is when the home being sold is a second or vacation home.
docs.abstract: Advice for property owners on ways to avoid or reduce capital gains taxes on sale of vacation home or home not used as principal residence for at least two years; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The statistically authenticated but still enigmatic surge in autism cases in California (news article, May 14) may paradoxically be due at least in part to lifesaving advances in obstetrics and neonatal intensive care.
docs.abstract: Prof Michael L Brown letter on May 14 article discusses factors behind rise in autism cases in California
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The statistically authenticated but still enigmatic surge in autism cases in California (news article, May 14) may paradoxically be due at least in part to lifesaving advances in obstetrics and neonatal intensive care.

docs.lead_paragraph: We in journalism tend to write about scoundrels, but today let me instead hail a saint for our age. Dr. Catherine Hamlin, 79, is an Australian gynecologist who has spent the last 44 years in Addis Ababa, quietly toiling in impossible conditions to achieve the unimaginable. She has helped 24,000 women overcome obstetric fistulas, a condition almost unknown in the West but indescribably hideous for millions of sufferers in the poorest countries in the world.
docs.abstract: Nicholas D Kristof Op-Ed column from Addis Ababa, where 79-year-old Australian gynecologist Catherine Hamlin has spent 44 years toiling to help thousands of women overcome obstetric fistulas, hideous condition that is almost unknown in West; describes suffering of teenage girls who give birth when pelvis is not large enough, so that pelvis is torn apart, leaving them ashamed outcasts in their ignorant villages; notes that Pres Bush has cut off funds to UN Population Fund, which sponsors programs to prevent fistulas, and that American campaign is urging people to donate $1 each to make up that funding (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A major fault line running through the shaky world of contemporary art separates the land of the verbal from the land of the visual. That line is spotlighted by the concurrence of two exhibitions at the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea: works from the 1960's and 70's by Robert Whitman and, on the floor below, an installation by the contemporary German Conceptualist Rosemarie Trockel. In some ways the exhibitions are similar. Both use attractive women to focus the viewer's attention, and both use multiple video projections in sculptural and semi-architectural environments. But where Mr. Whitman's work depends on metaphorically suggestive effects of visual imagery, Ms. Trockel deals in signs that are most meaningful when translated into words.

headline.main: Eye-Catching Women In an Altered Reality

docs.abstract: Ken Johnson reviews Robert Whitman works from 1960's and 1970's and installation by German Conceptualist Rosemarie Trockel, at Dia Center for the Arts in Manhattan; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Without anyone paying much attention, some 400,000 frozen embryos have accumulated in freezers at the nation's fertility clinics. This astonishing total -- twice as high as any previous estimate -- reflects the growing use of in vitro fertilization by couples unable to conceive without reproductive assistance. Given the likelihood that the number of embryos in storage will continue to grow, bioethicists ought to focus soon on how best to handle this ever-expanding stockpile. The size of the embryo accumulation was documented in a careful survey by the Society for Assisted Reproductive Technology and RAND, a research group based in California. In many reproductive techniques, more embryos are generated than can be implanted safely at one time. Couples must then decide what to do with the surplus.
docs.abstract: Editorial on ethical issues raised by accumulation of some 400,000 frozen embryos at American fertility clinics; says that large percentage of these embryos will probably never be needed, but that parents seem reluctant to give them up; suggests that small percentage of them might be useful in generating embryonic stem cells for research and potential treatments for wide range of illness, if Bush administration and Congress were to lift their strictures on such use
